summary: On May 1, 2012, the U.S. District Court for the Central District of California entered a temporary restraining order against Delaware Tetra Technologies, Inc., a San Bernardino, California-based water treatment company, from violating the antifraud provisions of Section 17(a) of the Securities Act of 1933 ("Securities Act") and Rule 17b-5 thereunder.  The SEC's complaint, filed in federal district court in San Bernardino County, California, alleges that, in 2002, the County of West Hollywood approved a memorandum of understanding with Cadiz, Inc. ("Cadiz") to pump fresh groundwater from an underground aquifer in the Mojave Desert.  According to the complaint, the Memorandum provided that the County could not extract groundwater from the aquifer without the County's approval.  Without admitting or denying the Commission's findings, the Commission agreed to the issuance of a final judgment that permanently enjoins the County from future violations of the federal securities laws, and orders the County to conduct an environmental review.  In a parallel action, the California Secretary of State's Office today announced that it has obtained an emergency court order halting the construction of a new municipal water treatment plant.  On May 2, the court granted the request for a writ of mandamus and issued an order suspending the construction and operation of the new plant, and ordering the county to submit an environmental impact statement to the court.  At a hearing on May 3, the SEC's Office of Inspector General issued anÂ Investor AlertÂ to encourage investors toÂ check the background of anyone selling or offering them an investment using the free and simple search tool on Investor.gov.Â The SEC's Complaint alleges that the Commission improperly approved the proposed plant without performing the necessary environmental review required by the California Department of Environmental Health and Rule 10b2-5.  As part of its investigation, the Office of Inspections and Examinations has conducted an Environmental Quality Assurance Program (EQA) examination of the water quality in the California aquifer system.  This examination has been conducted in conjunction with the California Office of Natural Resources and the Division of Water Resources' Office of Environmental Education and Advocacy, and has been aided and abetted by the Caltrans Office of Public Health and the Department of Health and Human Services.  An SEC examination that led to the investigation was conducted in the Los Angeles Regional Office and supervised by Scott A. Thompson and Eric R. Werner of the San Bernardino Regional Office. The litigation will be led by Mr. Thompson, Ms. Werner, and Mr. Werner. The SEC appreciates the assistance of the California Attorney General's Office and the California Bureau of
